title: Job Quiz - Complete Book
description: Test your comprehensive knowledge of the entire book of Job with 25 questions covering key events, people, and teachings from all 42 chapters.

questions.question: Who is described as perfect and upright, fearing God and eschewing evil at the beginning of the book?
questions.explanation: Job is introduced as a man perfect and upright, fearing God and turning away from evil.

questions.question: How many sons and daughters did Job have?
questions.explanation: Job had seven sons and three daughters according to the text.

questions.question: What was the total number of Job's sheep?
questions.explanation: Job had seven thousand sheep as part of his great wealth.

questions.question: What did Job do for his children after their feasts to sanctify them?
questions.explanation: Job offered burnt offerings for each of his children, fearing they might have sinned.

questions.question: Who came to present themselves before the LORD along with Satan?
questions.explanation: The sons of God came to present themselves before the LORD, and Satan came among them.

questions.question: What was Satan's response to God's question about Job's righteousness?
questions.explanation: Satan argued Job only fears God because he is blessed and protected.

questions.question: What did God allow Satan to do to test Job?
options: Touch all he had except Job himself
questions.correctAnswer: Touch all he had except Job himself
questions.explanation: God permitted Satan to touch all Job's possessions but not to harm Job himself.

questions.question: What calamity struck Job's oxen and servants according to the first messenger?
options: Sabeans fell upon them and took them away
questions.correctAnswer: Sabeans fell upon them and took them away
questions.explanation: The Sabeans attacked and took away the oxen and killed the servants.

questions.question: What was Job's immediate reaction after hearing about his children's death and losses?
options: He rent his mantle, shaved his head, and worshipped
questions.correctAnswer: He rent his mantle, shaved his head, and worshipped
questions.explanation: Job mourned but worshipped, showing his faithfulness despite loss.

questions.question: What did Job say about the LORD's giving and taking away?
options: The LORD gave, and the LORD hath taken away; blessed be the name of the LORD
Why does the LORD punish me?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD gave, and the LORD hath taken away; blessed be the name of the LORD
questions.explanation: Job accepted God's sovereignty with blessing despite his suffering.

questions.question: What was the result of all Job's initial trials as stated at the end of chapter 1?
options: Job sinned not, nor charged God foolishly
questions.correctAnswer: Job sinned not, nor charged God foolishly
questions.explanation: Job remained blameless and faithful despite misfortunes.

questions.question: What physical affliction did Satan inflict on Job in chapter 2?
questions.explanation: Satan afflicted Job with painful sores all over his body.

questions.question: What did Job's wife advise him to do during his suffering?
questions.explanation: Job's wife urged him to curse God and abandon his faith due to suffering.

questions.question: How did Job respond to his wife's advice?
options: He rebuked her and did not sin with his lips
questions.correctAnswer: He rebuked her and did not sin with his lips
questions.explanation: Job maintained his integrity and refused to curse God.

questions.question: Which friend came first to comfort Job?
questions.explanation: Eliphaz was the first friend to arrive and speak to Job.

questions.question: What is the main theme of Eliphaz’s first speech?
options: The wicked suffer and the innocent are rewarded
questions.explanation: Eliphaz insinuates Job’s suffering is due to personal sin.

questions.question: According to Zophar in chapter 11, what is God’s attitude toward Job’s iniquity?
options: God exacteth of thee less than thine iniquity deserveth
questions.correctAnswer: God exacteth of thee less than thine iniquity deserveth
questions.explanation: Zophar claims God’s judgment is even lighter than Job’s sins deserve.

questions.question: What does Job say about the fate of the wicked in chapter 21?
options: The wicked live long and prosper before their destruction
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked live long and prosper before their destruction
questions.explanation: Job observes the apparent prosperity of the wicked despite their end.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT an observation Job makes about the wicked in chapter 21?
questions.explanation: Job notes the wicked do not repent; they live in apparent security.

questions.question: What rhetorical question does Job ask about the Almighty in chapter 21?
options: What is the Almighty, that we should serve him?
questions.correctAnswer: What is the Almighty, that we should serve him?
questions.explanation: Job questions the benefit of serving God amidst apparent injustice.

questions.question: What does Job say about the fate of both the righteous and the wicked in chapter 21?
options: Both lie down alike in the dust
The wicked are always punished immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Both lie down alike in the dust
questions.explanation: Job notes that both the righteous and wicked ultimately die and are covered by worms.

questions.question: In chapter 31, what kind of covenant does Job say he made?
options: Covenant with his eyes not to look lustfully
Covenant with God to be obedient
questions.correctAnswer: Covenant with his eyes not to look lustfully
questions.explanation: Job vowed not to look upon a maid lustfully.

questions.question: What does Job ask to be weighed in an even balance in chapter 31?
questions.explanation: Job wants God to weigh his integrity fairly.

questions.question: What punishment does Job say is due if he has been unjust to his servants?
questions.explanation: Job acknowledges destruction from God as a terrifying punishment for injustice.

questions.question: What example does Job give about withholding from the poor or widows?
options: He would be guilty of sin
He did not know any poor
questions.correctAnswer: He would be guilty of sin
questions.explanation: Job confesses it would be sinful to withhold from the poor or widows.

questions.question: How does Job describe his openness to travelers?
options: He opened his doors to the traveler
questions.correctAnswer: He opened his doors to the traveler
questions.explanation: Job states he did not lodge strangers in the street but welcomed them.

questions.question: What does Job say about hiding his transgressions as Adam did?
options: He did not cover his iniquity
questions.correctAnswer: He did not cover his iniquity
questions.explanation: Job claims he did not hide his sins as Adam did.

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'Then Job answered the LORD, and said, I know that thou canst do every ______, and that no thought can be withholden from thee.'
questions.explanation: Job acknowledges God's omnipotence and omniscience.

questions.question: True or False: Job's friends agreed with him that he was innocent and undeserving of suffering.
questions.explanation: Job’s friends insisted he must have sinned to deserve his suffering.

questions.question: True or False: Job cursed God after losing his children and possessions.
questions.explanation: Job did not curse God but worshipped despite his losses.

questions.question: True or False: Satan was allowed to take Job’s life as part of the testing.
questions.explanation: God forbade Satan from harming Job's person.

questions.question: True or False: Job’s wife supported him in his faith throughout his trials.
questions.explanation: Job’s wife urged him to curse God and die.

questions.question: True or False: Job believed he could fully understand God’s ways by searching.
questions.explanation: Job’s friends say no one can find out God to perfection, implying Job did not fully understand.

questions.question: True or False: Job’s friends accused him of hypocrisy and sin throughout their dialogues.
questions.explanation: Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar repeatedly accuse Job of wrongdoing.

questions.question: True or False: Job laments the prosperity of the wicked in chapter 21.
questions.explanation: Job questions why the wicked live long and seem powerful.

questions.question: True or False: Job made a covenant with his eyes to avoid lustful thoughts.
questions.explanation: Job declared he would not look upon a maid lustfully.

questions.question: True or False: Job concluded his speeches by declaring his own sinfulness and unworthiness.
questions.explanation: Job maintained his innocence and integrity throughout.

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'Naked came I out of my mother's womb, and naked shall I ______ thither.'
questions.explanation: Job acknowledges the fleeting nature of life and possessions.

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'If I have walked with vanity, or if my foot hath hasted to ______;'
questions.explanation: Job calls for God to weigh his integrity honestly.

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'For destruction from God was a terror to me, and by reason of his highness I could not ______ him.'
questions.explanation: Job expresses reverence and fear of God's majesty.

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'If the men of my tabernacle said not, Oh that we had of his ______! we cannot be satisfied.'
questions.explanation: Job denies that his household envied or coveted others' flesh.

questions.question: What was God's final response to Job at the end of the book?
options: God spoke out of a whirlwind, questioning Job's understanding
questions.correctAnswer: God spoke out of a whirlwind, questioning Job's understanding
questions.explanation: God challenges Job’s knowledge and perspective from a whirlwind.

questions.question: What did God do to Job after his trials were over?
options: Restored his fortunes and gave him twice as much as before
questions.correctAnswer: Restored his fortunes and gave him twice as much as before
questions.explanation: God blessed Job with double his previous possessions and more children.

questions.question: How many additional children did Job have after his restoration?
questions.explanation: Job had seven sons and three daughters again after his restoration.

questions.question: What is a major theme of the book of Job?
options: The mystery of suffering and God's justice
questions.correctAnswer: The mystery of suffering and God's justice
questions.explanation: The book explores why the righteous suffer and God's justice in the face of that.
